docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: You are right about the need to ''fix'' the No Child Left Behind law (''Needed Fixes for No Child Left Behind,'' editorial, Feb. 15), but you do not mention the most crucial fix: The law rightly calls for radical increases in expected levels of learning, but never provided for the radical change in the deeply entrenched 19th-century system and system culture that is unable to produce these 21st-century goals. Even your correct emphasis on ''plans to train and retain'' high-quality teachers will fail if this obsolete system is left intact, since it does not provide a professional culture that will attract and hold enough of such teachers.
docs.abstract: Five letters comment on Feb 15 editorial on No Child Left Behind law; David S Seeley says new learning goals cannot be achieved by schools alone; Jerrold Ross advocates federal system under which uniform incentives for teachers are created; Ashley Offt Casale says government should finance education more than warfare; Ken Curtis says segment of school population is simply not equipped to learn because of array of social and economic obstacles; Walt Gardner says even if 75 specific recommendations are carried out, they will do little to help those most in need; drawing

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: There is no doubt that there is a health care crisis. There are now 47 million uninsured Americans.

headline.main: The Only Solution For Health Care

docs.abstract: Ernest A Canning letter contends solution to health care crisis is to adopt single-payer system in which costs of adminstration and pharmaceuticals are strictly regulated (Feb 16 Paul Krugman Op-Ed column)

docs.lead_paragraph: Patricia Ceglio and Bruce Johnson were married Friday evening on John’s Island in Vero Beach, Fla. Judge Robert L. Pegg of the 19th Judicial Circuit Court in Indian River County, Fla., officiated.
